site_title: US Republicans playing with fire
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

US Republicans playing with fire

Listen to this article

Published Tue, Oct 8, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE imbroglio over the US government shutdown, and the debt ceiling, might have been just a piece of political theatre had it not been so serious. The fact that a small group of radical Republican lawmakers can engineer an operational shutdown of most of the US federal government for a few days is unpleasant enough for thousands of government workers and millions of Americans who depend on public services.

But when those lawmakers also threaten to prevent the US debt ceiling from being raised - which must be done before Oct 17 - it is a potential threat to not only the US but also the global economy, and has set off alarm bells as far away as Beijing and Tokyo. If the legal limit on how much the US government can borrow is not increased within a week, Washington will not have enough cash to meet its liabilities. The potential consequences of this could be apocalyptic. In particular, there would be doubts over whether the US would be able to make interest payments on its Treasury bills - which are supposed to be the world's safest financial instruments. This explains why China and Japan (the largest holders of Treasuries) are concerned. The wider market consequences of a US default could include, among various things, a sharp hike in US interest rates - which would tip the American economy back into recession and take the global economy down with it, and cause major shocks to financial markets around the world.

Economists caution that it would be complacent to argue that a technical default by the US government - reflecting a temporary, legally created inability to pay rather than an unwillingness to pay - would be no big deal; a default lasting even a few days would cause severe market damage.

site_title: Planning the rest of your life
content:
Planning the rest of your life

Instead of keeping up with the Joneses, just spend a little less than your peers

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Oct 6, 2013 · 10:00 PM

WHEN thinking about the little question of how to live for the rest of your life, numbers can loom large, especially if you're not born with a silver spoon in your mouth. These cold, hard figures are necessary to do business with life.

They can be classified under two broad categories which, imagined as gigantic billboards, read "SPEND" and "EARN". "Spend" is far more complicated than "earn".

A place of one's own in Singapore, for example, might cost up to $1 million if you're looking at a condominium apartment, and half that if you're married and looking to buy new public housing.

Then, there are other nitty-gritty details, generalised very grossly as: rent or mortgage payments, eating out, groceries and bills, transport, a domestic helper, clothes and shoes for women, gadgets and other toys for men, tuition for kids, healthcare, upkeep for parents, the occasional holiday abroad.

Under "earn", most people will have only a single item: their monthly pay cheque.

That's a huge inequality right there. We don't even need to get into the income gap. And so many people feel they do not have control over their finances.

There is only one number contributing to the credit column of their bank account at the end of every month. By contrast, there is a seemingly infinite list of debits.

For the working young, the picture gets grimmer given low interest rates and longer lifespans. Do you really want to work every year, month, day, and endure the daily MRT crush, for the next 30 or 40 years until you hit 65? And even after all that, will you have enough saved to survive the next 30 years of retirement, given that you can live well into your 80s and even 90s on current life expectancy trends?

The number-crunching can get overwhelming and people reach for their financial adviser or insurance agent.

But sometimes, the details don't matter so much when it comes to deciding how to spend and earn.

One gauge people focus on is what their peers are doing. This phenomenon, known as "keeping up with the Joneses", refers to the powerful influence of people's spending decisions on their neighbours, colleagues and friends.

If most people around you are dirt poor, like Singapore in the 1960s and 1970s, you'd be happy watching some monochrome TV for entertainment at the end of a long hard day at work.

During the weekend, a movie is a treat. There is not much keeping up to do.

Today, society is far richer and more diverse. More than ever, people are also bombarded by a torrent of information on how other people around them lead their lives. Facebook is an effective way to show off your latest gourmet restaurant meal or that deluxe holiday to Bhutan.

The public sharing of these experiences tread the fine line between conspicuous consumption and the edge of cool - enough to elicit admiring nods and "likes" of approval from your friends, but perhaps make them a little envious. The race to get ahead does not just cover the "spend" category. Right from graduation, some people will dominate the "earn" rankings, making six figures a year straight out of school, getting 12-month or 24-month bonuses, and so on. What's a young and reasonably competitive person to do?

Given the inevitable benchmarking against one's peers, a certain strength of mind and perspective is needed.

Strength of mind is needed to catch up, if income equality is all you are after. After all, if you cannot make as much as your friends, then work on saving more.

There are many items in the "spend" category, but just one in "earn".

For those with tiring day jobs, it can be easier to cut costs than to figure out how to earn more money. Once even a few thousand dollars are saved, investing that can bring a few hundred dollars of dividends to add to the "earn" category every year. Part-time jobs can bring more.

A high savings rate, even on a below-average wage, goes a long way. Earn $2,500 a month but save half of that, and you'll hit $90,000 by the end of six years without having to invest a cent.

Without saving, even the above-average earners fall short. Bloomberg recently featured a 77-year-old former vice-president of marketing for multinational oral hygiene firm Oral-B, who earned the low six figures at the height of his career. But he managed to save only US$90,000 by 2008, before the financial crisis gave his investments a beating.

The will to cut down on costs is one thing. Getting some perspective is another. Singapore's median income last year was $3,000 a month.

About a third of locals earn under $2,000. Many don't have the luxury of planning for retirement, but will have to depend on their children or the state.

Other than empathising with the less fortunate, the other way to gain perspective is to look ahead.

If you're really going to live into your 90s, the wealth accumulation game is a marathon, not a sprint.

There is no telling what will befall the world in between. But there will always be opportunity.

The group, formerly known as Goldtron Ltd, had requested a trading halt on the Singapore Exchange on Oct 3. Its counter last traded at 0.3 cents. Yesterday evening, the group requested its trading halt to be lifted with effect from this morning.

FINALLY, one longstanding issue overhanging the global aviation industry appears to have been resolved. And in a civilised way, one might add.

At the close of the 38th Assembly of the United Nations International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) last week, an agreement was reached committing the organisation, which regulates and oversees global aviation, to develop a global market-based measure (MBM) which would help the industry achieve carbon-neutral growth from 2020 (CNG2020). A global MBM will also complement progress on improving technology, operations and infrastructure in the industry's long-established four-pillar strategy to manage aviation's climate change impact.

Not surprisingly, the International Air Transport Association (Iata) was quick to welcome the deal hammered out to tackle the hot button issue of Climate Change. And as its director-general Tony Tyler noted, reaching this agreement among ICAO's 191 member states was a challenging task.

site_title: TV and Web ad dollars are not made equal: IPG
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

TV and Web ad dollars are not made equal: IPG

The distinction can spell the difference between a successful ad campaign and one which makes little to no impact on the consumer, reports VICTORIA HO

Published

Sun, Oct 6, 2013 · 10:00 PM

A TELEVISION commercial is not absorbed the same way when it is on the Internet, and your online dollars could easily go to waste if you do not consider the difference, warns Neeraj Gulati, director for social media, World Markets Asia at IPG Mediabrands.

IPG Mediabrands is a media agency belonging to IPG, one of the big four global advertising agencies.

Mr Gulati told BizIT that viewers watch online video while they are engaged and actively interacting with the PC. "When you're on the computer . . . you're searching for content yourself, compared with being served images."

TV, in contrast, he described as a "lean back" medium - users are watching more passively and letting the broadcaster dictate what they are seeing.

This translates to better brand recall on laptops and PCs, compared with TV.

That distinction, he said, can spell the difference between a successful ad campaign and one which makes little to no impact on the consumer. Advertisers that try to cut corners by commissioning one video for both online and offline media are the most likely to fall into this trap.

The concept of "lean back" consumption is not just used in the advertising world. The computing industry has adopted the term to describe the difference between interacting on tablets compared with PCs, and publishers are taking it into consideration when putting out different versions of their products for paper, tablet, PC and mobile.

For video, said Mr Gulati, advertisers are not going to be able to force feed commercials to viewers online, as they have been accustomed to on TV. "You see about 40 TV ads in an hour, with the average 22-minute portion of an hour of TV being given to ads. You won't see 40 ads in an hour when you're surfing, though," he said.

Furthermore, the TV commercial format is fairly antiquated and does not translate well online. "Typically, you start by demonstrating a problem, then you show the product and how it works. That format's been around for decades."

A viewer watching this online is more likely to just hit the skip button. "The challenge is to make the ad desirable in the first five seconds before the skip button appears. So, you need to think about content, storytelling, and how the ad sits within the website," Mr Gulati says.

These observations combine with a important statistic - a whopping 80 per cent of consumers in Singapore watch videos online, he said. "You can't ignore the online channel, even for traditional companies. You can't push all of your money onto the online medium, because TV still has the highest penetration. But you must start investing where the impact is growing."

The tech industry has recognised the rapid migration of eyeballs over to the online world in recent years. Apple has been quietly building new features and content into its Apple TV service, as it prepares to challenge other technology players and broadcasters.

This year, it added two major content sources in the form of HBO Go and WatchESPN to its roster, and partnered with online sites such as Crunchyroll, to add content to Apple TV. It said in June that users now purchase over 800,000 TV shows per day via iTunes.

Rival firm Microsoft has also made video a core feature of its upcoming next-generation Xbox One console, opening the door to video-based advertising on its system.

Nearer home, Chinese search giant Baidu in May purchased PPS, an online video site, for US$370 million. At last count, iQiyi had a 200 million monthly mobile viewership.

Fellow Chinese giant Alibaba has plans for a smart TV set-top box, which will work with smartphones to allow people to surf and shop on their TVs. Users will also be able to take their video content on the road, streamed to their mobile phones. Again, this opens a clear window for commercials to be fed to users, cutting out TV broadcasters altogether.

The move away from the traditional TV is key, especially in Asia. According to comScore estimates in August 2012, Chinese viewers watched 4.1 billion hours of Web video in the month alone.

Mr Gulati pointed out that the mobile format should be treated differently from laptops and tablets. "Mobile screens have lower brand recall compared with TVs or PCs, because of the smaller screen size."

Advertisers should consider other modes of making mobile video more interactive, in order to have the message "stick", he suggested. Users also tend to share interesting snippets on the Web via the mobile, disseminating this to friends on platforms such as Facebook and Twitter. "Speak to the user with a thousand friends on Facebook, and who may be willing to share your message with them," he said.

Companies which want to influence purchasing intent should focus on PCs first, before tablets, then mobiles last, he added.

site_title: HDB resale prices slip in Q3, further declines seen
content:
HDB resale prices slip in Q3, further declines seen

Flash data from HDB shows 0.7% fall in index, first decline in over 4 years

Published

Tue, Oct 1, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Some analysts have put further price declines for resale Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats on the table, after the resale price index (RPI) fell for the first time in more than four years in the third quarter of the year.

Flash estimates from HDB yesterday put the index at 205.1 in Q3, a 0.7 per cent drop from the previous quarter. This is the first time that the RPI has fallen since the first quarter of 2009, at the outset of the global financial crisis, when it lost 0.8 per cent.

Consultants were not surprised by the drop, as a combination of cooling measures, and new or tweaked government regulations over the year took their toll.

"The decline was to happen sooner or later," said Eugene Lim, key executive officer at ERA Realty, as the resale market continues to show signs of stabilising.

Said Nicholas Mak, executive director for research and consultancy at SLP International: "This contraction is partly contributed by the government's efforts to cool the public housing market, which resulted in the decline of ... cash-over-valuation (COV) in recent transactions, especially for larger HDB flats."

The COV cash premium took a hard dive in the third quarter, figures from estate agencies show. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, ERA said overall median COVs fell 33.3 per cent to $18,000, with the biggest absolute falls in terms of quantum coming from executive flats.

The $18,000 figure overall tallies with PropNex Realty's data, which noted this was a 40 per cent drop from the $32,000 median COV at the start of the year.

Resale volumes did not fare any better. ERA data showed that the number of transactions fell 36.7 per cent quarter-on-quarter to 3,193 units in Q3, with the largest decline of 41.9 per cent coming from the executive flat segment.

Demand in Q3 was hit by factors such as a tighter Mortgage Servicing Ratio (MSR) on HDB housing loans and a Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) framework introduced in June.

"Due to a cut off in access to large loans and hence 'easy money', there are very few buyers looking at investing in large or well-located flats," said Ong Kah Seng, director at R'ST Research.

A recently-introduced three-year wait for new Permanent Residents (PRs) before they can buy a resale flat and the loosening of regulations for singles to buy BTO flats has also diverted demand away from the secondary market.

On the supply side, the pipeline remains ample, with HDB on track to launch 25,000 Build-to-Order (BTO) flats this year. Next month, it will offer close to 8,000 units under BTO and Sale of Balance Flats exercises.

Mohd Ismail, CEO of PropNex Realty, said the abundant supply may have created a "re-balancing effect" in the resale market, gradually softening price growth to a more sustainable level.

Sellers are now also less willing to cash out without a sufficiently attractive offer, as they may not have enough to buy another flat with similar attributes due to the tighter MSR terms, said ERA's Mr Lim.

He expects resale transactions to hit a historical low at below 20,000 units this year, and that COVs will fall to around $10,000 by the end of the year.

"With lower COVs, lower resale transaction prices are expected. As we see more lower priced transactions, flat valuations will also come down."

Analysts generally did not see price trends picking up in Q4, as sales are traditionally slower over the festive period, and as new property measures introduced in late August work their way through.

For the year, resale flat price growth could be anywhere from minus 1 per cent to 2 per cent, they predicted. PropNex's Mr Ismail believes resale prices could fall as much as 3 to 5 per cent next year.

R'ST's Mr Ong feels buying interest could pick up in the second half of 2014, when an "equilibrium point" is reached where prices and COVs come down to the point of being more affordable.

"Even (if) demand stabilises or slightly recovers from H2 2014, sellers cannot easily raise prices, since the MSR cap essentially restricts buyers from borrowing excessively to finance the flat," he said.

site_title: High temple to hedonism
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

High temple to hedonism

Published

Fri, Oct 4, 2013 · 10:00 PM

House of Dandy

74 Tras Street

Hours: 5pm till late, closed Sunday

Opens mid-October

www.facebook.com/houseofdandy

THE spirit of hedonism is alive and thriving in Singapore - and House of Dandy stands proudly as a temple of it.

"People in Singapore love their shopping, food and drink, but they seek pleasure in a culturally sophisticated way - that's exactly what dandyism is about," says Zara Fenley, co-owner of the upscale Tras Street bar set to open in the middle of this month.

The 2,200 sq ft, 60-seater bar is a nod to the dandy, an 1800s concept of middle-class men who highly valued physical appearance, refined language, leisurely hobbies and other trappings of an aristocratic lifestyle.

It takes its design cue from the men who have epitomised the movement across the ages: from 1960s Andy Warhol paintings and century-old Beau Brummell-inspired brass soap dispensers in its bathroom, to the Oscar Wilde quotes that will run across the main lounge area which, according to Fenley's fiance and business partner, Guy MacGregor, will be fashioned after "old gentlemen's clubs at the turn of the century". Top-of-the-line Tom Dixon lamps, wood and iron bar stools from Arteriors and Aviator Tomcat chairs inspired by World War II fighter aircraft keep it all to theme.

To keep it all very 2013, an award-winning mixologist will be roped in to create molecular cocktails in "flamboyant flavours influenced by cultures around the world," adds Ms Fenley. Five new cocktail creations will be introduced each month, starting with a selection of Singapore-inspired tipple for the opening month, such as white wine sangria tinged with chrysanthemum and lychee. If you're feeling peckish, simple bar snacks such as beef and salmon carpaccio, cold cuts and gourmet hot dogs will be on hand - and remember to keep your nonchalant cool should your cocktail be served with a moustache attached to its straw.

"We're going to be fun, playful and creative - we want people to take a photo of their drinks and enjoy it aesthetically as well as in taste," says Ms Fenley. "Instead of being just a bar that serves drinks, we hope to provide an entire lifestyle experience."

A Singapore PR of Thai-Chinese and British-Spanish descent, Ms Fenley left her marketing job earlier this year to serve as the team's creative director. Mr MacGregor, meanwhile, is a Scotsman who has lived in Singapore for eight years. His family owns a private investment company with interests in the oil and gas, property and technology fields.

The bar will be managed by Jamie Lee Gibb, a Scotsman and long-time friend of Mr MacGregor's who has previously run top clubs in the United Kingdom such as Mal Maisons and Dizzy.

The couple plan to open a second bar by the middle of next year, says Mr MacGregor, "and we'll keep the luxury element for sure".

But though upscale, House of Dandy, which cost $500,000 to set up, will not be an exclusive members' bar. Nor will it be one that admits only men - as gentlemen's clubs of the day used to do.

"After all, you can't have hedonism if there's only one gender around," quips Ms Fenley with a grin.

site_title: Washington braces for debt limit showdown
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Washington braces for debt limit showdown

Published

Thu, Oct 3, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] The fight over the government shutdown quickly moved on Wednesday to a bigger showdown over raising the nation's debt ceiling, as the first White House talks to solve the fiscal standoff failed to make any progress.

President Barack Obama and business leaders warned that the clash has raised the chances of a historic default on the national debt, which would occur if Congress does not agree to raise the US$16.7 trillion debt limit later this month and could cause a new recession.

Mr Obama said investors should take more seriously the threat of a potential default, which global markets have brushed off for months as Washington's usual partisan theatrics.

"This time, I think Wall Street should be concerned," Mr Obama said on CNBC. "When you have a situation in which a faction is willing to default on US obligations, then we are in trouble."

And the Treasury warned yesterday that a US default on its obligations forced by Congress not raising the country's borrowing ceiling would have catastrophic effects.

"Credit markets could freeze, the value of the dollar could plummet, US interest rates could skyrocket, the negative spillovers could reverberate around the world, and there might be a financial crisis and recession that could echo the events of 2008 or worse," the Treasury said.

US stocks are starting to reel from the politics of uncertainty, with the Dow Jones Average down 0.7 per cent within the first half-hour of trading.

Investors also fretted about a report yesterday that showed growth in the US services sector cooled last month after approaching an eight-year high in August as the pace of new orders dipped and hiring slowed.

The Institute for Supply Management said its services index fell to 54.4 in September from 58.6 in August, which was the highest since December 2005.

Over at Capitol Hill, senior Republicans have begun to suggest that a broad agreement to overhaul entitlements and the tax code could be used as a resolution to both the shutdown and the debt limit dispute. But Democrats view that approach as hostage-taking and say Congress must reopen the government and authorise additional borrowing before serious negotiations can occur.

The partial government shutdown has furloughed 800,000 federal workers and appears likely to remain for an extended period of time. The next crucial deadline comes on Oct 17, the last day the Treasury Department estimates that the federal government is certain to have enough money to pay all its bills.

Investors have also been demanding higher interest rates for US Treasury bills in recent days, a sign of concern that the federal government could have trouble servicing its debt.

On Wednesday, there was growing realisation on both sides of the aisle that lawmakers will likely have to deal with resolving the debt ceiling issue at the same time as the government shutdown.

Still, Mr Obama and Senate Democrats have so far refused to negotiate over either issue, saying they have already agreed to locking in lower funding levels favoured by the Republicans and that paying the nation's bills - which raising the debt ceiling would do - is non-negotiable.

The government shutdown is beginning to hit the factory floor, with major manufacturers like Boeing and United Technologies warning of delays and employee furloughs in the thousands if the impasse persists. - WP, Reuters

site_title: Time to make Singaporeans 'hungry' again?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Time to make Singaporeans 'hungry' again?

Listen to this article

Published Wed, Oct 2, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPOREANS aren't too keen to work abroad - and this limits the country, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said recently. The reluctance of Singaporeans to take up overseas postings would constrain not only their own career progress in multinational corporations but also Singapore's potential in the world, he added.

The PM's exhortation might seem remarkable. Globally savvy, most Singaporeans can, of course, see that an overseas work or study stint would be invaluable for the exposure to a different culture, the tremendous learning and mind-broadening experience that it provides. But family issues - young children's education, spouse's career, care of elderly parents - typically stand in the way. To be sure, a good number of Singaporeans have ventured out, even beyond the usual destinations to far- flung corners of the globe, but the intrepid and spunky are still the exceptions by far. Employers find it a challenge to get suitably skilled and qualified Singaporeans to take up an overseas assignment for even a year or two. Yet for those who aspire to top posts in an MNC, an overseas stint, "even to difficult places", would be almost de rigueur. Said PM Lee: "We should have that spark to go wherever the opportunities are, and some of them will be hardship postings."

Contrast the situation elsewhere: many young French people, for instance, see greater opportunities outside their country, particularly in Asia, and France is worried about an exodus of talent. Indeed, with high youth unemployment across the continent, droves of young people from Greece, Spain, Italy, etc, have had to leave home in search of not so much greener pastures but simply a decent job and salary.

site_title: S Korean authority fines China Gaoxian 2b won
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S Korean authority fines China Gaoxian 2b won

Former chairman, CFO, underwriters also fined over 2011 KDR listing statement

Published

Thu, Oct 3, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SCANDAL-HIT China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings might have resumed trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) but its past has returned to haunt it.

The China-based fabric maker announced yesterday that South Korea's financial regulatory authority, Financial Supervisory Services (FSS), has imposed fines on the company and its former executive chairman Cao Xiangbin over irregularities relating to the listing of Korean Depositary Receipts (KDRs) in 2011.

Both were also referred to the prosecution in South Korea.

Also not spared fines were China Gaoxian's former chief financial officer Raymond Wong and two underwriters of the KDR listing.

China Gaoxian was fined two billion Korean won (S$2.3 million) over a securities registration statement lodged in 2011, the year when China Gaoxian raised $220 million via KRX through the issue of the KDRs.

FSS said that China Gaoxian had exaggerated its cash and cash equivalents at the time of its Korean listing by more than 100 billion won and did not disclose material facts relating to its Huaxiang Project to expand production.

Mr Cao was fined 50 million won and Mr Wong 16 million won.

The two underwriters - Daewoo Securities and Hanwha Securities - were fined two billion won (S$2.3 million) each for their failure to carry out proper due diligence.

China Gaoxian said yesterday that it had yet to receive a formal notice on the FSS decisions.

Under Korean law, the company will be entitled to file an administrative law suit within 90 days of the company's receipt of the notice, if it wishes to challenge its fine.

"In this regard, the company will consult with its legal advisers and deliberate on its response to the FSS decisions, including whether to file the aforesaid administrative law suit," China Gaoxian said.

China Gaoxian's share trading was suspended in March 2011 when auditor Ernst & Young could not verify the bank balances of two of the company's Chinese subsidiaries for the year 2010.

Last July, boutique asset manager Fleur Capital pumped $27 million into the company.

Shareholders have waived rights to claims against the company. Shares resumed trading two weeks ago.

Records for the first three months of 2011 are still missing, and China Gaoxian has said that the chance of recovering them in a reasonable amount of time was remote.

China Gaoxian's KDRs, which resumed trading last week, make their compulsory delisting exit from the KRX today.

On the local bourse, the counter ended trading at 7.2 cents yesterday, down half a cent or 6.9 per cent.

SUBSCRIBERS

Bureau Veritas opens deepwater tech research hub

Published

Tue, Oct 1, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Global assessment and certification services provider Bureau Veritas (BV) opened its Deepwater Technology Research Centre (DTRC) in Singapore yesterday.

Supported by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore's (MPA) Maritime Cluster Fund (MCF), the DTRC aims to provide advanced technical solutions and innovations to BV's clients in Asia-Pacific to reinforce the level and quality of its real-time support.

The DTRC is the first BV technology research centre in Asia and will benefit from the MCF, which was expanded in June 2013 to cover the setting up of R&D and test centres, thought to be critical components in developing a maritime knowledge hub.

"Singapore was chosen as the site for the DTRC because of its strategic geographical location and its current position as a leading hub for the building and conversion of offshore units. It was also deemed to be the ideal choice because it is very well served by quality institutions and higher education establishments, and because it has world-class infrastructural links and a well-established and widely respected R&D strategy," said Matthieu de Tugny, BV's vice-president for marine & offshore for South Asia.

BV said more than $7 million will be invested over five years in up to 10 R&D projects and it is in discussion with local stakeholders on possible collaborations.

"MPA is happy to support BV in the set-up of its Deepwater Technology Research Centre in Singapore. Since the expansion of the MCF scheme, this is the second R&D test centre to open in Singapore. We are encouraged by the positive response and we encourage interested companies to come forward with their proposals. The set-up of R&D and Test Centres will develop Singapore's capabilities in the field of maritime R&D and technology," said MPA chief executive Lam Yi Young.

The centre will provide a platform for the technologically innovative resolution of issues by highly skilled personnel.

Using BV's state-of-the-art software tools, the DTRC will be conducting applied research in the key R&D areas of hydrodynamics, hydro-structures, mooring and riser systems, computational fluid dynamics and renewable energy.

It will be headed by BV's research engineer Xiaobo Chen, who has been with the company since 1991 and was previously head of BV's hydrodynamic and mooring section and director of international R&D cooperation.

[TOKYO] Japan Airlines (JAL) and ANA Holdings' fight over additional slots at Tokyo's Haneda airport, Asia's second-busiest, is widening to include global airline partnerships seeking access to fly business people right into the heart of the city.

site_title: HK home prices to fall 30% by end-2015: Barclays
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

HK home prices to fall 30% by end-2015: Barclays

Published

Mon, Oct 28, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[HONG KONG] Barclays plc joined UBS AG and Bank of America Corp in forecasting a Hong Kong property slump, predicting that home prices will fall at least 30 per cent by the end of 2015 as income growth stalls and supply increases.

A "downward spiral of home prices is likely" as developers and homeowners adjust expectations, analysts Paul Louie and Zita Qin wrote in a report yesterday. They assigned a "negative" rating to the Hong Kong property sector and said that office prices will drop 20 per cent.

Barclays' forecast exceeds the predictions of a series of brokerages that have downgraded Hong Kong property this month and implies the biggest plunge in prices since 1998. Hong Kong home prices more than doubled since the start of 2009 on record-low interest rates and lack of supply, prompting the government to impose extra taxes and tighten lending restrictions.

"The magnitude of the fall is underestimated," the Barclays analysts wrote.

The analysts are advising investors to sell eight of the 14 Hong Kong property companies it covers, including Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd, the city's second-biggest builder, Swire Properties Ltd, New World Development Ltd and Wharf Holdings Ltd.

Cheung Kong Holdings Ltd, controlled by Li Ka-shing, Asia's richest man, and Hang Lung Properties Ltd, which made more than 50 per cent of its revenue outside Hong Kong in the first half, are the only two property stocks Barclays recommends investors to buy.

The Hang Seng Property Index, which tracks nine of the biggest developers listed in the city, including Sun Hung Kai and Cheung Kong, has declined about 14 per cent since peaking in January.

Developers in the first half sold 4,300 residential units, the fewest since the second half of 2008, after the government in February doubled stamp duty taxes on property transactions over HK$2 million (S$320,000).

To make up for the first half's slowing sales, developers will need to cut prices to attract buyers, said the Barclays analysts.

Prices will come under pressure as household incomes and residential rents peak, while housing supply is set to increase, the analysts said. Hong Kong's average household income was little changed in the second quarter, while rents are "starting to hit the income ceiling", they said.

Chief Executive Leung Chun Ying, who has pledged to increase land supply since coming to office in July 2012, said in January that the private sector may sell 67,000 homes in the next three to four years. Hong Kong developers completed 48,936 homes from 2008 to 2013, the lowest in any five-year period since data became available in 1985.

Hong Kong home prices last year surpassed a previous peak in 1997 and are now the world's highest, according to realtor Savills plc, after having more than doubled since 2009. They have fallen about 2.7 per cent since rising to a record in March, according to an index compiled by Centaline Property Agency Ltd.

Raymond Ngai of Bank of America's Merrill Lynch unit and UBS's Eva Lee are among analysts who over the past month have forecast home prices in the city will drop as much as 25 per cent as demand wanes because of government curbs and the expectation of rising interest rates. Since 2010, Hong Kong has introduced a raft of measures, including extra property transaction taxes and tighter mortgage-lending requirements, to damp prices and avert a housing bubble. Total residential transactions in the first half fell to the lowest since 1996, according to data available on the Land Registry's website.

Hong Kong's real estate market may also face pressure as the US Federal Reserve prepares to trim stimulus, according to the Merrill Lynch and UBS analysts. Mortgage costs in the city tend to track interest rates in the US because the Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the US currency.- Bloomberg

site_title: NTUC conference backs wage model, PME push
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

NTUC conference backs wage model, PME push

Delegates reaffirm that the moves are in workers' long-term interest

Published

Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] After three days of brainstorming, the labour movement agreed that the progressive wage model (PWM) that they launched last year was its best hope to keep wages growing, said labour chief Lim Swee Say.

And the best hope for growing its ranks - another key issue - is to get more professionals, managers and executives (PMEs) into the labour movement's fold. This was the conclusion of the 650-plus union activists at the biennial National Trades Union Congress' (NTUC) Ordinary Delegates' Conference which ended yesterday.

"There's no running from the progressive wage model, there's no running away from reaching out to the PMEs," Mr Lim told reporters after the conference yesterday.

Delegates at the three-day pow-wow reaffirmed that the PWM and PMEs are "strategic" and in the long-term interest of workers.

The PWM reflects NTUC's plan to help workers of different sectors achieve sustainable wage increases "through the tailoring of wage ladders unique to each job sector". It aims to enable workers at all levels to upgrade and progress to the next wage point under a progressive wage model.

While the PWM has been rolled out, delegates felt that the training support needed still had not been formally put in place, according to Mr Lim, who is NTUC secretary-general and also Minister in the Prime Minister's Office. They reckoned that the training has to be structured and widespread.

The same holds true for the national push for higher productivity growth, the delegates said.

They also called on NTUC to beef up its service to PMEs as more join the labour movement. But they also cautioned against neglecting rank-and-file members who remain the backbone of the labour movement.

With membership hitting 800,000 this year, the labour movement is within sight of reaching its goal of one million members by 2015. Along with the push for the PWM and to reach out to more PMEs, as well as to extend tripartism to the ground level, the conference recognised the need to build and develop a strong core of labour leaders, said Mr Lim.

As NTUC moves to grow and develop its current pool of 6,200 union leaders, Mr Lim said that there was a need to take a "whole of labour movement" approach. This means that leaders will be identified and nurtured at all three levels in the labour movement - the national or NTUC, sectoral and union level.

A "development circuit" will be set up to groom labour leaders "in a systematic manner with a slew of initiatives, such as training programmes, mentoring schemes and opportunities to learn and contribute to assignments", he revealed.

Delegates at the conference also urged the labour movement to step up its engagement with the management and human resource community to speed up the implementation of the PWM and reach out to PMEs.

They also suggested that the labour movement broaden its engagement with relevant government agencies "so that there is mutual understanding and closer collaboration between both parties in making both our economy and workers future-ready".

site_title: Cyber resilience needed to counter next-gen adversaries
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Cyber resilience needed to counter next-gen adversaries

Published

Sun, Oct 6, 2013 · 10:00 PM

AS the world gets more connected and devices are integrated with an Internet Protocol (IP) address, the opportunities to orchestrate cyber attacks by next-generation adversaries are growing exponentially.

Security experts say this is why it is more important to increase the resilience of one's IT systems and possess the information and tools to fight back against online criminals, than to develop security architectures to fend off attacks.

Anthony Bargar, the former cyber security adviser at the US Office of the Secretary of Defense, said at last week's GovernmentWare 2013 conference that there is a need to increase organisations' cyber resilience given the trends emerging in security threats today.

He said online attacks are moving from the simple extrication of data and money from targeted entities to something more destructive in nature; he cited the example of Stuxnet - a highly sophisticated piece of malware specifically targeting SCADA (supervisory control and data acquisition) systems used in critical infrastructure - and reported by the New York Times to be jointly developed by the US and Israeli governments to specifically slow down Iran's nuclear programme.

Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs), of which Stuxnet was an extreme example, are commonly used by cybercriminals now that the tools and methodologies are out in the wild, and this has raised the level of risks faced by governments and businesses today, Mr Bargar said.

"The cyber destruction posed by these next-generation adversaries have replaced the nuclear bomb as (today's preferred) form of deterrence," he said during his presentation.

Tony Chew, director and specialist adviser to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), who also made a presentation, reiterated Mr Bargar's assessment of today's threat landscape, particularly within the financial services and insurance (FSI) sector.

He said the top three security threats faced by those in the sector are from internal sources, external parties and system failures. The dangers from within, for instance, include IT administrators who have unfettered access to the network. They then turn rogue and release sensitive information.

He cited Edward Snowden, the NSA (National Security Agency) whistleblower who released sensitive information regarding the US government's supposed monitoring of citizens' communications, as an example of an insider threat.

This is why the MAS has internal regulations that implement the "never alone" principle, in which no system administrator can have the singular ability to create master passwords or backup data, Mr Chew said.

Another MAS policy is the segregation of responsibilities between IT administrators involved in day-to-day operations and those in charge of data backup and recovery functions, he added.

Besides implementing policy, Mr Bargar also called on organisations to build up their overall resiliency when an online attack takes place. The ability to suffer an attack, yet recover quickly to a trusted environment, means minimal downtime while allowing them to investigate the attackers and hit back, he explained.

Mr Bargar added that having "active defence" architecture also involves expanding internal intelligence gathering and developing an early warning system. Citing a study by the Ponemon Institute, he said the lack of real-time cyber threat intelligence cost each enterprise an average of US$10 million over a 12-month period.

To have a resilient active defence strategy, companies need to map out the cascading impact of potential security breaches from a single point of vulnerability. This is so that they know where their "crown jewels" are and how to safeguard them in a proactive manner, he advised.

Getting employees onboard is also critical in raising the overall security readiness of organisations, Mr Bargar pointed out. One way is to offer staff real-time training and simulation to actual attacks in order to increase awareness and preparedness.

"Companies can organise cyber war games and have blue and red teams battle it out to test out the robustness of their systems, and root out any potential vulnerabilities," he said.

site_title: Plunge prompts calls for circuit breakers
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Plunge prompts calls for circuit breakers

Almost US$7b wiped out over 3 days as shares of three firms dive

Published

Wed, Oct 9, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Singapore Exchange (SGX), South-east Asia's biggest bourse, faces calls from investors to add circuit breakers after a plunge in shares of three commodity companies erased US$6.9 billion in value over three days.

The bourse operator imposed unprecedented trading restrictions on Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital and LionGold Corp after their stock prices plunged.

Trading caps to prevent sharp gains or losses will give investors time to assess their holdings, according to Liquidnet Holdings Inc and the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), or SIAS.

Regulators worldwide have evaluated safeguards since the May 2010 plunge - known as the flash crash - briefly erased about US$862 billion from the value of US equities. American exchanges have implemented a limit-up/limit-down initiative that prevents market makers from quoting shares at prices deemed too far above or below current levels.

"It's more important now because today there's so much electronic trading," Seth Merrin, founder and CEO of New York- based Liquidnet, operator of trading platforms for mutual funds and asset managers, said in an Oct 7 interview in Singapore. "That's how a stock can go down from US$40 to a penny. I'm 100 per cent in favour of circuit breakers."

Regulators around the world have stepped up oversight of capital markets after the global financial crisis in 2008. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) established a 13- member council in 2010 with the goal of boosting corporate governance standards and investor confidence.

While existing rules in Singapore are sufficient for company disclosures, regulators may need to introduce an "early warning" system for investors, said David Gerald, president of SIAS, the largest organised investor lobby group in Asia.

"SIAS calls on SGX to implement the circuit-breaker mechanism immediately to help prevent wild fluctuations of stock prices to enable investors to digest the information available in the marketplace during the break and make informed decisions," he said in a statement on Tuesday.

The exchange said on Oct 6 that shares of the three companies have been declared designated securities, prohibiting investors from selling them unless they hold the same quantity of stock. Buyers must make cash payments for the transactions, it added. Carolyn Lim, a spokeswoman for the bourse, didn't immediately comment on the call for circuit breakers on Tuesday and couldn't be reached in her office yesterday.

Blumont, which invests in minerals and energy, slumped 94 per cent over two trading days on Oct 4 and Oct 7, before closing unchanged on Tuesday. That shaved S$4.9 billion off its market value, prompting the company to scrap a proposed S$146 million acquisition of Australia's Cokal Ltd.

The stock rebounded earlier on Tuesday, more than doubling after Alexander Molyneux, former CEO of SouthGobi Resources Ltd, invested in the company. He will buy 135 million Blumont shares and become chairman after the purchase is completed, the company said. Mr Molyneux, who was ousted as CEO of SouthGobi last September, is a director of Ivanhoe Energy Inc. Blumont climbed as much as 58 per cent yesterday before closing the day 46 per cent up at 19 Singapore cents.

"It's not for us to comment on the restrictions," Mr Molyneux said at a press conference in Singapore on Tuesday. "The exchange does their job, they have their rules, and we do our job. Whether or not any regulatory issues caused the share-price slide, I believe it created a unique value opportunity and that's why I bought the stock."

Kelly Teoh, a strategist at IG Markets in Singapore, said last week that short-sellers are taking advantage of the "weak market sentiment". She said on Tuesday that Mr Molyneux's investment in Blumont should stem further selling in the stock.

Before the selloff, Blumont was the best performer on Singapore's broader FTSE ST All-Share Index after a more than 12-fold increase in the first nine months of the year.

Asiasons, which last month bought a stake in US oil-and-gas producer Black Elk Energy Offshore Operations LLC, tumbled 96 per cent over three trading days through Tuesday, shaving S$2.5 billion in market value.

The stock, which was the second-best performer on the FTSE ST All-Share Index, more than tripled in the nine months through September. The company said on Oct 4 that rumours that it was being investigated by regulators were false. The shares climbed 38 per cent to 16 Singapore cents yesterday.

LionGold, which said this week that it was in advanced negotiations for a possible acquisition of Minera IRL Ltd (a gold explorer in Peru, Argentina and Chile), plunged 87 per cent over the three-day period, wiping off S$1.2 billion in market value. The shares climbed 42 per cent in the first nine months of the year. They fell 0.5 per cent yesterday to 18.9 Singapore cents.

The swings in the prices of these companies are "worrisome signs" that should be investigated, said Jim Rogers, chairman of Singapore-based Rogers Holdings. Still, he's against the introduction of circuit breakers.

"They should let the market take care of itself," he said in a phone interview on Oct 7. "Circuit breakers are absurd. It's just another interference for the market."

Circuit breakers could also affect investor perception, said Andy Maynard, global head of trading and execution at CLSA Ltd in Hong Kong, adding that Singapore should keep its market open and free.

Trading limits are "just part and parcel of doing business in those markets where there isn't a concept of a free market in the first place", he said in an e-mailed response yesterday. "As long as participants are able to settle and deliver stock, then stocks should rise and fall on their own attributions."

Still, the call for circuit breakers comes one month after Everbright Securities Co announced a 523 million yuan (S$106.4 million) loss after US$3.8 billion in erroneous trading orders that roiled China's equity market and drew a record regulatory penalty that banned four of its executives from the market for life.

Markets including South Korea, India and Taiwan use circuit breakers, while countries including Japan have daily price limits depending on their value, according to CLSA. - Bloomberg

site_title: Apec business leaders: stable markets crucial
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Apec business leaders: stable markets crucial

They also appeal for more infrastructure investment

Published

Mon, Oct 7, 2013 · 10:00 PM

BUSINESS leaders from Singapore and the rest of the Pacific Rim urged their governments yesterday to strengthen financial markets to contribute to the inclusive growth of the region.

Against the backdrop of an uncertain global economy, they also called on the 21-member grouping to develop a "more ambitious" agenda on trade, investment and services.

These were among the recommendations that the Apec Business Advisory Council (Abac) made in a 50-page report submitted to Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono yesterday.

Dr Yudhoyono, the host of this year's Apec Summit meetings in Bali, was present at a dialogue with the council along with the leaders of the 20 other Apec economies, including Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

The report was signed by all 63 Abac members, including Singapore's trio comprising Blackstone Singapore chairman Gautam Banerjee, Singapore Business Federation CEO Ho Meng Kit and United Engineers group managing director and CEO Jackson Yap.

The Abac members completed their fourth and final meeting of the year in Bali last week as they put the finishing touches on their recommendations to the leaders.

"While economic conditions have improved this year, Abac remains concerned over the continuing uncertainty that pervades the global economy, including volatile capital flows and unstable financial markets in the Asia-Pacific region," said the council.

There is still much to be done to underpin the resilience and openness of Apec economies such that the region can become a more secure engine of global growth, it added.

Abac also appealed for significant infrastructure investment across the Asia-Pacific to sustain growth and open new opportunities, as well as to integrate Apec economies into regional and global markets.

But the business leaders also noted that Apec economies would be unable to fund the region's "massive" infrastructure deficits without funding from the private sector.

"We will need to utilise more Apec savings and develop more innovative financing arrangements. The lack of ready infrastructure projects and slow implementation of public-private partnerships (PPPs) are a real concern to investors," said the Abac report.

The council also encouraged Apec leaders to ensure that their respective economies remain open to cross-border investment and to promote a broad understanding of the benefits of foreign direct investment as a driver of sustainable growth and employment.

Singapore's PM Lee described the Abac dialogue as a "useful platform to engage business leaders informally on issues that are important to the development of regional economies".

content:

Mapletree Industrial Trust DPU up 7.9%

Gross revenue rises 7.6% in Q2 on higher rental for all property segments

Published

Tue, Oct 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

MAPLETREE Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.47 cents, a 7.9 per cent increase from the 2.29 cents a year earlier, on higher rentals and occupancies.

Distributable income rose 9.7 per cent year-on-year to $41.1 million for the three months ended Sept 30, 2013.

MIT's portfolio of 83 properties, valued at some $2.9 billion as at end-March, are classified into five categories: flatted factories, business park buildings, hi-tech buildings, stack-up/ramp-up buildings and light industrial buildings.

Gross revenue increased 7.6 per cent from a year ago to $73.4 million in Q2, on higher rental rates secured for leases across all property segments, as well as higher occupancies in flatted factories and stack-up/ramp-up buildings.

This, combined with lower property operating expenses, helped net property income grow 11.6 per cent to $54 million.

Tham Kuo Wei, chief executive of MIT's manager, Mapletree Industrial Trust Management, described its portfolio as resilient, with gross revenue up 1.6 per cent from the previous quarter despite the exit of a major tenant.

The average portfolio occupancy fell to 93.9 per cent, from 95.5 per cent in the previous quarter, mainly because of this exit. The average passing rent for MIT's properties edged down to $1.70 per square foot (psf) per month from $1.71 psf per month in Q1.

For the half year ended Sept 30, DPU was 4.9 cents, up 7.7 per cent from a year ago. Distributable income was 9.4 per cent higher at $81.3 million. The trust's gearing stands at 36.2 per cent.

MIT expects rental income to increase from two projects. Its build-to-suit development for Kulicke & Soffa, K&S Corporate Headquarters at Serangoon North Avenue 5, received its temporary occupation permit earlier this month and is 72 per cent pre-committed. Meanwhile, an asset enhancement initiative at Toa Payoh North Cluster 1 is also on track for completion in the third quarter of its fiscal year.

MIT said that while industrial rents should remain stable in the near term if there are no unexpected major shocks to Singapore's economy, a large supply pipeline of industrial space may exert downward pressure on rents in the mid term.

The counter closed 0.7 per cent lower at $1.365 yesterday.

M&L gets permission to expand Sydney hotel

It'll add third tower with 230 rooms to the 683-room Four Points by Sheraton

Published

Thu, Oct 17, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore-based M&L Hospitality has got the greenlight to add even more rooms and features to what is already Australia's largest hotel by number of rooms.

Yesterday, the New South Wales government approved M&L's plans to add a third tower to the Four Points by Sheraton hotel in Sydney's Darling Harbour, adding 230 rooms to its existing 683.

The tower will also add 53,800 square feet of commercial space, including Grade A offices, and 51,800 sq ft of exhibition, convention and function space.

The project, the first to break ground in a planned revamp of Darling Harbour, will cost more than A$160 million (S$190 million).

Michael Kum, the chairman of M&L Hospitality, said: "M&L sees great opportunity in the Australian hospitality market - particularly in Sydney - and this investment is our vote of confidence in the market."

Work is expected to start early next year and will be completed within two years, with minimal disruption to hotel operations.

M&L Hospitality, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Grandline International backed by the Kum family in Singapore, took ownership of the hotel in 2009 and refurbished all 683 of its rooms. This two-year exercise was completed only last month.

Neil Maxwell, the chief executive of M&L Hospitality, said: "We have been committed to bringing out the hotel's full potential through investment."

Mr Kum expects the extensions to the hotel to alleviate a current shortage of hotel rooms and convention space in Sydney's central business district (CBD).

Darling Harbour, located in the CBD, is to be remade into a convention, exhibition and entertainment precinct at an expected cost of A$1 billion.

Australia is to develop the International Convention Centre (ICC) Sydney, its largest convention and exhibition space, which will be ready by around 2016.

The Four Points was M&L Hospitality's first Australian hotel investment. Also in the company's Australian portfolio are the Swissotel Sydney, Travelodge Docklands in Melbourne and Citigate Melbourne.

The company owns another eight hotels in Singapore, London, Japan and New Zealand.

ST Aerospace clinches projects worth $600m in Q3

Published

Wed, Oct 16, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE Technologies Aerospace, an arm of Singapore Technologies Engineering, clinched $600 million worth of new orders in the third quarter, with projects including freighter conversions, cabin retrofitting as well as airframe, component and engine maintenance.

In a press release issued yesterday, the group said that one of the contracts secured in Q3 was an order of 17 passenger-to-freighter (PTF) conversions for an international air cargo carrier. This takes the total number of aircraft under ST Aerospace's Boeing 757-200 PTF conversion programme to 119.

ST Aerospace also received a cabin reconfiguration project from an Asia-based airline to work on two Boeing 767-300 aircraft. Separately, it was awarded a Supplemental Type Certificate (STC) by the European Aviation Safety Agency for a full cabin retrofit of six Airbus A330 aircraft for an international carrier.

In Q3, ST Aerospace redelivered a total of 245 aircraft for airframe maintenance and modification works as well as redelivered five Boeing 757-200 converted freighters. Aside from airframe redeliveries, "the aerospace sector processed 11,360 components, 59 landing gears, 57 engines and conducted 1,570 engine washes for both commercial and military customers".

ST Aerospace is also trying to widen its reach by growing its engine leasing and pilot training sectors. Its wholly owned subsidiary, ST Aerospace Engines, recently ploughed additional capital into Total Engines Asset Management (TEAM), in which it holds a 50 per cent stake. TEAM has placed out 10 engines so far. It has also expanded its leasing portfolio to include the International Aero Engines V2500 engine.

Meanwhile, its commercial pilot training academy has been certified by the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) as a Type Rating Training Organisation, enabling the academy to carry out aircraft type conversion training leading to CAAS type ratings.

A fixed-based Airbus A320 FFT X™-MPL simulator has been commissioned at its training academy at Seletar Aerospace Park. With a fully type-specific cockpit, the simulator is designed to support multi-crew pilot licence (MPL) Phase II training.

Shares in ST Engineering closed at $4.20 yesterday, up three cents.

site_title: Big car premium hikes 8.4% as COEs spike up
content:
Big car premium hikes 8.4% as COEs spike up

Cat B rises $7,261 to $93,500; Cat A up $1,249 to $85,000

Published

Wed, Oct 9, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] COE premiums spiked up across the board yesterday, with the big car category unexpectedly closing in on the $100,000 mark.

In the first bidding exercise of October for certificates of entitlement, Category A - for cars below 1,600cc - rose $1,249 to $85,000, while Cat B - for cars above 1,600cc - surged $7,261 or 8.4 per cent to $93,500.

The last time an equivalent COE category cost more than $100,000 was 19 years ago.

Cat E - the open category - climbed $6,888 to $93,889 as it tracks Cat B.

Meanwhile, Cat C - for goods vehicles - was $309 higher at $76,310, and Cat D - for motorcycles - inched up $258 to $1,961.

Some dealers seemed to think the increase in the Cat A COE premium is due to a backlog of orders as well as both panic buying and selling.

"The number of bids in Cat A was close to double the 365 COEs available," said the sales manager of a volume brand in explaining the backlog.

He added that the looming re-categorisation of Cat A has also sparked panic among both buyers and sellers. From February 2014, the engines of Cat A cars not only have to be limited in displacement to under 1,600 cc but their power also cannot exceed 97 kW or 130 hp.

Because of this, some sellers are keen to offload existing stock before the deadline.

"So even if COE goes up, it is better for them to clear their stocks now before it becomes even more expensive later," he said.

As for the spike in the Cat B COE premium, the sales manager was nonplussed. "I didn't expect it to jump so much, so I was outbid," he confessed, explaining that the Leng Kee Road motor belt was "quiet" over the past three weekends.

He said: "The second weekend was especially quiet although it was slightly better during the most recent weekend. I don't know who could be bidding for COEs so aggressively."

Yesterday's rise in the Cat B premium was likely the result of the relatively small gap between it and the Cat A premium after the previous tender, said the director of a luxury brand.

"It was small, less than $2,500, so interest shifted to Cat B," he said. "It's the usual ding dong story. It should swing back now that the gap has widened."

He said it is unlikely that the sharp rise in Cat B was caused by the new Mercedes-Benz S-Class because launch prices are not firmed up yet.

Rather, he believes the most plausible reason is that one of the luxury makes is the sponsor of next February's Singapore Airshow, an event for which it has to register more than 500 cars.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

KKR invests RM642m in M'sia helicopter services firm

Published

Thu, Oct 10, 2013 · 10:00 PM

GLOBAL investment firm KKR has invested RM642 million (S$252 million) for a "substantial minority equity stake" in Malaysia's Weststar Aviation Services Sdn Bhd (WAS), an offshore helicopter services company.

The injection of funds is expected to help pay for 10-year-old WAS' expansion plans into West Africa, Indonesia and Thailand, which it has identified as growth areas. The investment, KKR's first in Malaysia, was sealed via a partnership agreement signed in Kuala Lumpur yesterday.

Founded in 1976 and helmed by Henry Kravis and George Roberts, KKR has some US$84 billion in assets under management and has located its South-east Asia regional headquarters in Singapore.

The firm's investment comes ahead of WAS' public share sale anticipated next year.

WAS group managing director Azman Syed Ibrahim said: "We do have plans, but want to grow the company before we move on to an IPO (initial public offering)."

KKR member and regional head of South-east Asia Ming Lu said an IPO was "not a near-term priority, but one of the options".

WAS' fleet now comprises 35 helicopters, mainly AugustaWetlands; it has acquired another 10, two recently delivered.

Mr Azman has often been referred to by the Malaysian media as one of the country's top "AP Kings" for being one of the biggest beneficiaries of import permits required to bring in completely- knocked down vehicles. (AP stands for Approved Permit.)

Critics of the country's controversial AP system, established to give bumiputras a leg-up in the automotive sector, contend that the permits are often sold for between RM40,000 and RM50,000 each, depending on the make of the vehicle.

Under trade pacts, the AP system is to be dismantled from 2015.

In a speech sketching the history of WAS, Mr Azman noted that the firm had started with just one helicopter and five staff. The business took off sharply in 2008 after it won a bid from state-owned Petronas Carigali to provide offshore aviation services; more contracts followed in 2011, including a 10-year multi-billion-dollar deal to provide oil and gas rotary wing services to five oil majors in the region.

Domestically, the aviation sector has attracted considerable private investments in the last two to three years, courtesy of prioritisation by the government.

Mr Azman said WAS now services 16 firms, and that it was looking to KKR not only for funding, but also for insights into "how to manage a big operation".

Mr Lu described WAS as having "tremendous growth opportunities" from the strong demand driven by robust oil and gas activities.

KKR's investments in the region include Avogo, Unisteel, Masan Consumer and PT Tiga Pilar Sejahtera Food Tbk.

From hippie haven to hip street

Jaegersborggade is no longer a favourite haunt for biker gangs and drug dealers, as foodie gangs have taken over the street. By Geoffrey Eu

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Oct 18, 2013 · 10:00 PM

WHEN Christian Puglisi and Kim Rossen decided to open a restaurant in Copenhagen a few years ago, they settled on a derelict building in the middle of Jaegersborggade, a cobblestone street running through a dodgy part of town in the Norrebro district. It was a hippie haven for counterculture types, populated by biker gangs, drug dealers and streetwalkers, but the space suited their budget and they had a daring plan to make an impact on the city's fast-growing fine-dining scene - helping to transform the street for the better.

"We took a biker club and turned it into Relae - it was a perfect spot for shady business but even better for a restaurant," says Puglisi, a noted young chef with impeccable culinary credentials (El Bulli, Noma). "We knew that what we were doing could give the street a push - our food would conquer the street, and then the city."

A casual observer walking down Jaegersborggade will be unaware of its colourful past. Many of the 19th-century buildings are unrestored, but while parts of the street are still rough around the edges - unwittingly pointing your camera at certain buildings and residents hanging around street corners will provoke a negative response - there is an unmistakable sense that the gentrification of Jaegersborggade is here to stay.

site_title: Watchable and heartwarming
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Watchable and heartwarming

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE story of babies being switched at birth is a common yarn tackled by many filmmakers both on the big and small screens. With a bit of craft and originality, it can be twisted into either a comedy or drama.

Japanese director-writer Hirokazu Kore-eda goes for the latter in his latest film Like Father Like Son; he also turns it into a slow-burning tearjerker. It's the arthouse filmmaker's most accessible work to date because of the familiar subject matter he had chosen to explore and execute in his typical low-key style.

Bar one very obvious hanky moment in the third act, the rest of Like Father Like Son tugs gently at the audience's heartstrings, putting a lump in their throats rather than trying to make them bawl their eyes out throughout.

Not one to exploit the melodrama cheaply, Kore-eda goes for a sensitive light touch, allowing the story to unfold quietly rather than shoehorning the film with a series of dramatic moments.

Singer-actor Masaharu Fukuyama plays Ryota, a workaholic salaryman whose perfect world with his wife, Midori (Machiko Ono), is turned upside down when the hospital informs them that the boy Keita (Keita Ninomiya), whom the couple has been raising for the last six years as their son, isn't actually theirs.

A mix-up had resulted in two infants being switched at birth and the couple's real son, Ryusei (Hwang Sho-gen), had gone on to be raised by another couple, Yudai (famed author and illustrator Lily Franky) and Yukari (Yoko Maki). The hospital arranges for both sets of parents to meet and discuss the possibility of doing a switch so they get their right boys back.

Kore-eda paints a contrasting image of both couples - Ryota and Midori are cool urbanites while Yudai and Yukari are bohemian small-town folk. That also means that there's a difference in how they raise their boys.

As a perfectionist, Ryota demands that Keita makes no mistakes while Yudai is less concerned with disciplining Ryusei simply because he's a man-child himself.

The plot is slightly lopsided with the mums sidelined and having significantly smaller roles. A huge chunk of Kore-eda's story centres on the boys' relationships with their new dads. Too much focus is also given to Ryota's fixation on blood being thicker than water; hence his inability to accept Keita as his own, even though he's been treating the boy as his son before he found out the truth.

Like Kore-eda's 2004 latchkey-children drama Nobody Knows, the cute tykes steal the audience's hearts with their antics. Ninomiya, in particular, is a little heartbreaker turning on the charm offensive with his huge eyes and boyish innocence.

It might not be Kore-eda's finest hour but the Japanese auteur has spun a watchable and heartwarming tale out of a familiar premise to make Like Father Like Son feel like his own.

Rating: B-

site_title: Orchestrating tableau of big data
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Orchestrating tableau of big data

Tableau Software wants to be the data crunching tool for everyone

Published

Sun, Oct 27, 2013 · 10:00 PM

BACK in 2003, three Stanford engineers were huddled in Christian Chabot's bedroom, working on a data research project funded by the US Department of Defence.

Mr Chabot, Chris Stolte and Pat Hanrahan quickly realised that beyond the project, the business of data would become something big years down the road, when it would matter even to mainstream companies.

The three went on to found Tableau Software, which has been specialising in providing business intelligence and data analytics software from its inception.

"I was a data analyst earlier in my career after graduating. I was a number cruncher and I knew I needed better tools," Mr Chabot, Tableau's CEO, tells BizIT.

Fast forward to today and that bet paid off. The company is in the thick of a big data awakening in the tech industry. Industry analyst IDC estimates that between 2005 and 2020, the amount of digital bytes we have will grow from 130 exabytes to 40,000 exabytes.

Amid this trend, big companies are scrambling to put resources into churning out data analysis and business intelligence features in their products.

Looking at just German software giant, SAP, and its partners alone, collectively they will make US$220 billion together over the next five years based on big data, said IDC.

And McKinsey thinks that in the US, big data use could drive US$325 billion in extra annual GDP in the retail and manufacturing sector by the year 2020. Big data will also cut US$285 billion in costs in public and health care sectors in the country.

For Tableau, it's gathered significant momentum over the past few years. Revenue was US$34.2 million in 2010, growing to US$62.4 million the following year, and nearly doubling again to US$127.7 million in 2012.

The company also started trading on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in May this year, with Mr Chabot, Mr Stolte and Mr Hanrahan as CEO, chief development officer, and chief scientist of the company, respectively.

The big data story, however, wasn't always this obvious to the industry, Mr Chabot says.

"Ten years ago, no investors were talking business software at all - they were keen on consumer companies. The companies getting all the attention were sites like Monster, Google and Match.com.

"And so we bootstrapped the company for about three years, because we didn't convince investors during the early stages," he says.

Still, the founders stayed lean and doggedly chased the goal of pushing the company past the red.

"We've been cashflow-positive since the end of our first year," he says proudly. "But it took a lot of selling, because nobody knew what big data was. I would drive around Silicon Valley in my 1994 used Geo Prizm with a laptop in my trunk, and meet with companies from parking lot to parking lot."

Those meetings eventually led to a meeting with American supermarket chain Safeway. "It was our first US$10,000 sale. US$10,000! That's huge, especially when you're a small company," he says.

Safeway wanted Tableau's technology to help it slice and dice its Club Card loyalty programme member base, so it could improve the types of discounts pushed to individual members.

The applications of data crunching continue to expand, as more data-driven services enter the mainstream consumer consciousness, explains Mr Chabot.

"We never anticipated the rise of Facebook's social graph in 2003, or that tablets would increase the rate of data generated and consumed by everyone.

"But the fundamental problem is the same. We want to understand data. Underneath the changing platforms and devices, there is the need to understand data. A thousand years from now, that issue will remain," he says.

And as consumers get savvy with navigating intelligent searches on sites like Facebook, they're pushing enterprises to keep up, he adds.

"People use advanced platforms like Google and Facebook at home, and then they go to the office and are faced with antiquated systems. This dissonance helps drive change," he says, noting that the world's leading corporations could learn a thing or two from the way that Facebook has architected its database.

"The types of systems that Facebook rolls out is more advanced than anything a bank could, because Facebook is on a bigger cloud, its internal analytics is far more sophisticated, it has more data, and a younger workforce driving it," he says.

This admiration for the Facebooks and Googles of the world is why Tableau has set out to be the data crunching tool for everyone, he says.

"We don't want to attack the market by verticals. We want to be a horizontal tool giving people access to business intelligence without being systems specialists or statisticians."

Some of Tableau's competition beat the same drum. San Francisco-based Splunk, for example, was founded the same year as Tableau. Its Web-based interface is clearly designed to target the same group of Gen Z workers that Tableau professes to be courting.

On the mention of Splunk, Mr Chabot shakes his head, saying: "Splunk is a tool for IT people. It's programming-intensive, and it's focused on machine data so you still need to be able to write some code to make sense of it all. We are exactly the opposite. We're for everyone else: teachers, doctors, dentists. We're for anyone with a spread sheet or database."

And he isn't worried about larger companies building analytics functions into their products. With the way that data is exploding from every device out there, chances are it won't all be found in one place, defeating the purpose of running analytics on just one source.

"It's not all sitting in your ERP (enterprise resource planning) software. It's in the cloud, it's in your log files, in your Microsoft Excel sheets," he says.

The company sells itself to customers on the pitch that they'll need an agnostic tool to cover all these bases.

"Don't overthink it," says Mr Chabot.

At just 41 years of age, the executive is visibly excited to helm the company on its rapid expansion.

Its employee count, some 700 people in December 2012, has now hit 930, spread out across the globe.

The company is headquartered in Seattle, and has two more US offices in Menlo Park and Kirkland.

In 2011, it started expanding internationally, opening in London. In 2012 it launched its Singapore, Tokyo and Dublin offices, with Sydney coming on board most recently.

He's keen on sinking Tableau's roots deeper in Asia, where there are millions of growing SMBs (small and medium-sized businesses) ripe for the picking.

"SMB spending overall might be smaller than large corporates, but honestly, that's not the reason larger companies aren't able to service them as well. It's because traditional products are complex. If your product is easy to use, you can service SMBs in a sustainable way. Salesforce.com is doing that well, for example," says Mr Chabot.

For the first half of 2013, Tableau's Asia-Pacific business doubled compared with the previous corresponding quarter. In 2012, annual growth was 105 per cent year-over-year.

In Singapore, its customers tend to be larger corporations because of the high number of multinationals located here. It also counts the Singapore government as a customer.

The focus on SMBs also complements Tableau's recent focus on cloud-based products. In July, it started offering Tableau Online, a hosted version of its Tableau Server product. It's since attracted a base of 200 customers.

Mr Chabot foresees a future where cloud computing will eliminate IT departments entirely.

"Think about it this way. We're all in a talent war. Really cutting edge companies like Facebook, Google, Microsoft, we're all struggling to get data analysts and statisticians. And if the tech industry is struggling, how do you think your average bank out in the mid-West is doing in that regard?"

The point of cloud computing, he says, is that it's become the natural answer to the struggle to populate in-house IT departments with talent good enough for tomorrow's data issues.

"This is probably some way off, but at some point we'll look back and laugh at the age of IT departments. It's silly," he says.
